Dead by Daylight is a game that actually has replayable content that can feel unique each time and different. It has done it really well with the variety of killers, perks, maps, and different builds that are available. 

The game is good with friends. Definitely worth purchasing if you have a friend who frequently plays the game. 

If you like taking your emotions out on survivors then killer is the single player mode for you. Sacrifice them, or run that Ebony to track down those twitch streamers. 

The game is so unbalanced, just when you think it's balancing out, some hillbilly charges you with double move speed from across the map before you can say "Oh Crap". Some people say the unbalancing adds to the fun of the game, because it is unbalanced on both sides, it kind of evens out... In fairness, there is a way to play around most things in the game.

If you're new to the game, take your time mastering skill checks and getting used to the audio-queues. Learn the map layouts and pellet locations. Learn looping and understanding that if the killer is on someone, it is okay to do gens instead of squatting in the corner. Read up on the perks and used Google to answer any questions you may have. I'm sure the answer is out there. (like how could they improve legion? Answer: Delete).

A huge con of the game is survivor hitboxes (imagine being hit through a window.....) and slowvaulting at the worst possible time.

There are other cons to the game, but if you pay attention to patch notes, the game is under constant development, which addresses a fair few of the concerns/issues the community has (such as the lobby system, matchmaking, ping/host, etc).

The fact that the game is consistently under development is the major reason this game is recommended by me. Any issues that I have had with the game in the past, have been addressed at some point in the further development of the game. 

PS. Yeah you can get full tilt in this game btw. Not taking personalities into consideration for the reviews, because some people have no patience and some people are god tier non alt-f4s.

A game as unbalanced as somebody's mental state if they found it enjoyable. 

As a survivor, you are an underdog running on survival instincts and adrenaline. How do we make sure that players are able to manage going up against a killer who is fearless and powerful? Lets add benefits to the killers!

Yes, I know, this comes across as illogical, but it's a moronic reality that the game currently suffers from.

But how could the developers possibly formulate such a recipe for disaster? Well... they:
-Made it so Killers are faster
-Killers can sprint
-Killers can do a 180 in a split second
-Killer lair has a single exit/entrance
-Killer can camp the hooks
-Killer can repeatedly destroy generators
-Killer can use abilities to track players unless the players use an object to get rid of it
-Killer can crouch hide
-Door escape has a countdown timer
-Killer can gain levels throughout match to kill in less hits
-Killer can detect sprinting
-Killer can detect a player being still to long
-Hooks are covering the map
-Killer can... 

...alright, you get the idea. So do we find it odd and broken that the survivors have little to no advantages over the killer?
I think that it defeats the whole purpose of the game

If a player knows how easy it is to die immediately, it ruins the tension and fear the game tries to portray. It ends up being a repeating purgatory where you end up not caring about the killer. It ends up as a frustration that reminds you how little the developers care about any resemblance of balance.

Wait, but can't players hide and knock things over to slow down the killer?
I think it would be easier to explain how these mechanics have become flawed. It seems that the developers have forgotten about map design and have made sure that both hiding spots and blocking objects are nearly non-existent. 

Behind all of the glitches, terrible matchmaking, and awful map design, this game at its core is flawed and has only become more apparent as new killers are added which continues the theme of breaking the balance.

But for the big question, would I recommend this game? I don't think I could find any new players that wouldn't immediate see these flaws as I do. I also can't think of anybody who would want to suffer through a game that encourages the act of a molten lead enema.

This is an update on my review from October 2019 : most of the issues are still there.

I like the concept. I liked it when it worked, even with all its flaws.
So far many problem were more or less addressed by paid DLCs so be prepared to spend more than the base game if you want to have a chance against the other players.

The game itself is riddled with bugs.  Expect your power to fail you consistently or, if you play killer, to have your aim magically moved toward the last server-know position of an opponent who's lagging. (So, yes, lag-switcher are still there and contrary to the lies from the developer it's an advantage when kept in check, at least it is for the survivor side.)

The main problem of the game is that it has never been balanced properly.
Basically the developers are making it so new survivor players can win without having a clue.
It doesn't take a genius to ask the question : "But what does it means for experienced players?" and the answer is easy.  A team of experienced survivors will win most games.

Every veteran knew this already but now that there is finally a "skilled-based match making" (MMR) experienced killers soon get to play matches they have very little chance winning as well as cheaters.  This may be the reason why the population has dropped from about 100k to 50k in about 3 months (That and some serious, and free, competition being right on the corner).  You only need to look at how many "killer mains" streamers are now playing more and more survivors.

Still if you are choosing one the the few viable killers (Blight, Leatherface, Nurse) you may stand a chance ... up to a point. (Spirit has been nerfed : newbies rejoice, you will still not stand a chance but neither will she against good players.)

This culture of mediocrity makes the game awful for survivors playing alone too.
You only need to be paired with fools to get your "skill" level downed, starting down a spiral to hell.

Basically the only way to play this game and have some fun is as a group of 3 or 4 survivors : that's what I've done for the last few months.

Yes,yes VERY GOOD. Thank you

-Horrific matchmaking (played against people with 1,500+hours right out of the gate)
-Smurf and alts everywhere, with some of the more notorious players having 3-4 different steam accounts to play on
-Possibly the most toxic community I have seen on any game. 
-Constant crashes
-Relatively quick survivor queues but you can sit in queue as a killer for almost 15 min waiting for a game.
-"Community" that is outright hostile to newcomers
-Players disconnect nearly every game, many players will ragequit the second they are downed or put on a hook
-When a survivor disconnect, it reduces the chances of winning significantly, so much so that this often causes a domino effect of the rest of the team quitting.
-Ill-conceived progression system that requires literal millions of bloodpoints to unlock necessary teachable perks.
-Players are encouraged to exploit game mechanics in order to draw out the game as long as possible(Looping/slugging) in order to maximise the amount of bloodpoints earned.
-The Teachable perks required to make certain killers work take hundreds of hours of grinding to unlock
-2/3 of the killers and survivors are locked behind a paywall and can only be obtained using Auric cells, something that you must pay real money for with no option of obtaining them using one of the games many in-game currencies.
-DLC shop constantly shoved into your face 
-Most cosmedics are just lazy palate swaps
-Bad netcode, survivors interacting with palates from 10 feet away, the hitboxes are also greatly effected when playing as certain killers who rely on ranged abilities.
-Tutorial is too short and doesn't explain many necessary game-play mechanics
